skill.name: orchestrating-parallel-agents
skill.description: Spawns multiple AI coding agents to work on related GitHub issues concurrently using git worktrees. Use when breaking down a large feature into multiple issues, running parallel agents with --print flag, or managing wave-based execution of related tasks.
skill.summary: Spawns multiple AI coding agents to work on related GitHub issues concurrently using git worktrees. ...
skill.author: 4eyedengineer

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown instructions for git worktree-based parallel agent orchestration. No executable code, file system modifications, network calls, or external command execution by the skill itself. All 36 static findings are false positives from the scanner misinterpreting documentation patterns.

content.user_title: Run Multiple AI Agents in Parallel
content.value_statement: Managing multiple related GitHub issues sequentially wastes time and delays delivery. This skill enables running several AI coding agents simultaneously using git worktrees, breaking large features into parallel waves of independent work for faster feature completion.
actual_capabilities: Spawns multiple AI agents on separate git worktrees for concurrent work on related issues
Organizes issues into waves based on file dependencies to minimize merge conflicts
Provides issue templates with context for autonomous agent execution
Includes monitoring commands to track parallel agent progress and identify stragglers
Documents manual completion steps for git operations that require user permissions
limitations: Requires pre-approved git permissions in settings.local.json for non-interactive use
Agents cannot push or create PRs without explicit git permissions in configuration
Same-file changes across issues require sequential merging or single-agent handling
Users must manually resolve merge conflicts between waves of work

use_cases.title: Scale Team Velocity
use_cases.description: Break large features into parallel workstreams and accelerate delivery by running multiple AI agents concurrently on independent changes.

use_cases.title: Parallel Infrastructure Work
use_cases.description: Implement backend, database, and API changes simultaneously while keeping frontend work in separate dependency-aware waves.

use_cases.title: Feature Branch Isolation
use_cases.description: Run independent agents on different file changes without merge conflicts by organizing work into dependency-aware waves.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Parallel Spawn
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the parallel agents workflow to spawn agents for issues 101, 102, and 103 in parallel waves.

prompt_templates.title: Wave-Based Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: Break down the new authentication feature into 3 waves of independent issues using the parallel agents workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Monitor Progress
prompt_templates.prompt: Check the status of running parallel agents and identify any worktrees that need manual completion.

prompt_templates.title: Complete and Merge
prompt_templates.prompt: Complete the remaining git commits for stalled agents and merge the wave 1 PRs sequentially.

output_examples.input: Run parallel agents for issues 201 and 202 on the authentication feature
output: Created git worktrees for issues 201 and 202
Issue 201: User model changes in progress

output_examples.input: Organize a new payment feature into waves for parallel execution
output: Wave 1: Database schema changes (1 issue, 1 file)

output_examples.input: Check which parallel agents need manual git completion
output: Issue 103: Code complete, git failed - needs manual commit

best_practices: Keep each issue scoped to 1-3 files for higher agent success rates
Organize waves so independent changes run first to maximize parallelism
Include specific file paths and code snippets in each issue for faster agent context
anti_patterns: Spawning too many agents that exceed system resources and cause failures
Putting same-file changes in different waves without coordination
Skipping manual review of agent-generated changes before merging PRs

faq.question: What tools does this skill work with?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude Code and Claude. It uses the Task tool to spawn parallel agents on git worktrees.

faq.question: How many agents can run in parallel?
faq.answer: The limit depends on system resources. Start with 2-3 agents and increase gradually while monitoring performance.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with GitHub Actions?
faq.answer: Yes, run the parallel agents workflow locally and use GitHub Actions for CI/CD validation of completed PRs.

faq.question: Is my code safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill only provides workflow guidance. All code changes are reviewed by you before commits.

faq.question: Why did my agent fail on git operations?
faq.answer: Agents need pre-approved git permissions. Add permissions to settings.local.json or complete git steps manually.

faq.question: How is this different from multiple Claude sessions?
faq.answer: Git worktrees isolate changes to prevent conflicts, allow parallel work on the same repo, and simplify cleanup.
